fields.summary: [R] Installation of Arrow fails on Debian Gnu/Linux

comments.body: Hi [~amtrm], thanks for reporting this and sending the log output too.  Please could you run {{arrow_info()}} and {{session_info()}} and send the output of those as well?

{code:java}
> sessionInfo( )
R version 4.0.4 (2021-02-15)
Platform: x86_64-pc-linux-gnu (64-bit)
Running under: Debian GNU/Linux 11 (bullseye)
Matrix products: default
BLAS: /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/blas/libblas.so.3.9.0
LAPACK: /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/lapack/liblapack.so.3.9.0
locale:
 [1] LC_CTYPE=en_US.UTF-8 LC_NUMERIC=C 
 [3] LC_TIME=en_US.UTF-8 LC_COLLATE=en_US.UTF-8 
 [5] LC_MONETARY=en_US.UTF-8 LC_MESSAGES=en_US.UTF-8 
 [7] LC_PAPER=en_US.UTF-8 LC_NAME=C 
 [9] LC_ADDRESS=C LC_TELEPHONE=C 
[11] LC_MEASUREMENT=en_US.UTF-8 LC_IDENTIFICATION=C
attached base packages:
[1] stats graphics grDevices utils datasets methods base
loaded via a namespace (and not attached):
[1] compiler_4.0.4 tools_4.0.4
{code}
I cannot provide the output of `arrow_info()` as arrow is not installed. But perhaps this could help:

 
{code:java}
$ c++ --version
c++ (Debian 10.2.1-6) 10.2.1 20210110
$ gcc --version
gcc (Debian 10.2.1-6) 10.2.1 20210110
{code}

Also, I've managed to install Arrow on a plain Debian Bullseye docker container, so I guess the problems I'm having are due to some Debian package or library collision or version mismatch. I'll try to compare the docker to my system and see if that helps.

Ah, I see you've run {{arrow_info()}} as a script rather than from the package itself (which is fine!), that makes sense.  Please could you try setting the {{ARROW_R_DEV}} environment variable to true, and the running {{install.packages("arrow")}} and sending the output from that, just so I can see if there are any different error messages in there?
And can I also double check which other Arrow-related environment variables you've set?

Hey [~thisisnic] , it did the magic! With ARROW_R_DEV set to true `install.packages("arrow")` succeeded. Thank you very much!

I'd be happy to know why.

Also, I still have the arrow binary deb packages installed - do I need them / is it good to keep them? Or would it be better to remove them and re-install arrow without them?

Thanks again,

Amit

However, some capabilities are missing, like being able to read parquet, as we can now see

 
{code:java}
arrow::arrow_info()
Arrow package version: 5.0.0
Capabilities:
 
dataset FALSE
parquet FALSE
s3 FALSE
utf8proc TRUE
re2 TRUE
snappy TRUE
gzip TRUE
brotli TRUE
zstd TRUE
lz4 TRUE
lz4_frame TRUE
lzo FALSE
bz2 TRUE
jemalloc TRUE
mimalloc TRUE
To reinstall with more optional capabilities enabled, see
 https://arrow.apache.org/docs/r/articles/install.html
Memory:
 
Allocator jemalloc
Current 0 bytes
Max 0 bytes
Runtime:
 
SIMD Level avx2
Detected SIMD Level avx2
Build:
 
C++ Library Version 5.0.0
C++ Compiler GNU
C++ Compiler Version 10.2.1
 
{code}
I tried to fix that by
{code:java}
arrow::install_arrow(verbose = TRUE){code}
but it failed with the same error I had earlier.

Those capabilities are optional dependencies; please can you try installing again with env var {{LIBARROW_MINIMAL}} set to {{false}}, and if it doesn't work, please paste the whatever you ran to install it as well as the output, and I'll take another look.

Honestly, I'm not 100% sure as I'm new-ish to the project but the problems you're having sound like ones I've had before when I've had multiple versions of Arrow installed whether from a system installation or incomplete previous installation, and things have gotten mixed up.  This could be totally wrong - but your comment about the arrow binary deb packages made me think of it.  To clarify, when you say "arrow binary deb packages", are you talking about a system installation of Arrow rather than your R package and associated libraries?

By "deb packages" I mean I had run the commands in this [link|https://arrow.apache.org/install/] to intall Debian packages that are needed by arrow (that can be used, as far as I understand, instead of compiling them from sources).

I'll try to see if I can reproduce a successful installation and if I can enable parquet capabilities. I also think this is some kind of mix up, I'll see if I can understand that. Thank you very much for you time.
From that link, it looks like Arrow is installed as a system library, which may well be what's interfering here - do you want the system library or are you only interested in the R package?
Currently I only want to use arrow from R - I don't need the system libraries for themselves.

When Arrow is installed via {{install.packages()}}, it can install a version of the required Arrow C++ libraries.  It's much easier to let the install script in the package handle that than to have a system version as there's more scope for things to go wrong.

There's more info in the vignette here: https://arrow.apache.org/docs/r/articles/install.html

What I'd recommend is uninstalling the system libraries entirely, removing the R package you have installed, and then install again using {{install.packages()}} - a fresh start on this might sort things out.

Hi Nic, I'm still having problems, but I found a workaround that allows me to work, so here is a summary of the current status.
 * I managed to install Arrow in a Debian docker container without any problem;
 * I managed to install Arrow on another Debian machine (another laptop), but I had to update all system packages and all R packages; before that the installation of Arrow had failed;
 * On my main laptop, which also runs Debian, I'm still having problems installing Arrow, details below.

I removed all the arrow .deb packages, and tried to install arrow, but I got the same ld problem. I then updated all system packages and all R packages, it seems to be better - `install.packages("arrow")` manage to complete, but complained that it cannot find C++ libraries. I then ran `install_arrowl()` but it failed with the ld error I reported above. Now `arrow_info()` shows

 
{code:java}
> arrow::arrow_info()
Arrow package version: 5.0.0
Arrow C++ library not available. See https://arrow.apache.org/docs/r/articles/install.html for troubleshooting.
{code}
The link suggest to set LIBARROW_BINARY=true, I did that and tried `install_arrow()` again, and it again failed. I also tried other combinations for LIBARROW_BINARY and LIBARROW_MINIMAL but it didn't help

The workaround I finally found was to copy the arrow installation from the docker container to my laptop R/site-library directory. Both are running the same version of Debian, and that way Arrow is now working on my laptop, with all the capabilities I need. This is not perfect, but for now it solves my practical problem.

For now I'll stop trying to solve the problem of installing arrow directly on my system. However, if you want to investigate this further and I can help in some way, I'd be glad to do that.

Thanks again for your efforts,

Amit
